It's not the world's population per se that's the problem, it's how much of our resources each person uses that's going to become a problem in the relatively near future.
 Currently the US uses 26% of the world's energy with only 5% of the people. As developing countries begin to industrialise on a large scale, particlularly India and China with a third of the global population between them, their demand for energy will skyrocket. No matter how quickly we invest in new energy sources, demand will massively outstrip supply within our lifetimes, leading to global insecurity and increasing inequality, between and within nations.
 Not even taking global warming as a proven problem (which I do believe it is) the fact that the rest of the world wants to live like the rich West is going to cause us major problems. For example, although there are all sorts of theories about the total amount of fossil fuel left on the earth, most analyses agree that with current trends, demand will outstrip supply before the end of the decade, sending oil prices up (not even considering other reasons for this, such as potential increased instability in the middle east), with no chance of production being increased fast enough to bring the price back down.
 A lot of people in this thread seem to think that we could support far more people, but we simply cannot support more people who live like 'we' do in the rich nations. We would have to have a huge leap forward in clean energy production, and great economic sacrifices would have to be made before the benefits were seen. 
 We could, for example, put vast amounts of money into r&d for cold fusion,and if it proves feasible, an even greater amount of money into building enough reactors to power the world, but this will take a long time, and living standards would drop in the West as a result of the financial drain.
